00044 static inline size_t u_strlen(const char* s)
00045 {
00046         U_INTERNAL_TRACE("u_strlen(%s)", s)
00047 
00048         U_INTERNAL_ASSERT_POINTER(s)
00049 
00050         return strlen(s);
00051 }

00053 static inline int u_equal(const void* s1, const void* s2, uint32_t n, bool ignore_case) /* Equal with ignore case */
00054 {
00055         U_INTERNAL_TRACE("u_equal(%p,%p,%u)", s1, s2, n)
00056 
00057         U_INTERNAL_ASSERT_MAJOR(n,0)
00058         U_INTERNAL_ASSERT_POINTER(s1)
00059         U_INTERNAL_ASSERT_POINTER(s2)
00060 
00061         return (ignore_case ? strncasecmp((const char*)s1, (const char*)s2, n)
00062                                                           :      memcmp(             s1,              s2, n));
00063 }

00083 /* WILDCARD PATTERN - The rules are as follows (POSIX.2, 3.13).
00084 
00085 Wildcard Matching
00086  A string is a wildcard pattern if it contains one of the characters '?', '*' or '['. Globbing is the operation that
00087  expands a wildcard pattern into the list of pathnames matching the pattern. Matching is defined by:
00088 
00089  A '?' (not between brackets) matches any single character.
00090  A '*' (not between brackets) matches any string, including the empty string.
00091 
00092 Character classes
00093  An expression '[...]' where the first character after the leading '[' is not an '!' matches a single character, namely
00094  any of the characters enclosed by the brackets. The string enclosed by the brackets cannot be empty; therefore ']' can
00095  be allowed between the brackets, provided that it is the first character. (Thus, '[][!]' matches the three characters
00096  '[', ']' and '!'.)
00097 
00098 Ranges
00099  There is one special convention: two characters separated by '-' denote a range. (Thus, '[A-Fa-f0-9]' is equivalent to
00100  '[ABCDEFabcdef0123456789]'.) One may include '-' in its literal meaning by making it the first or last character
00101  between the brackets. (Thus, '[]-]' matches just the two characters ']' and '-', and '[--0]' matches the three characters
00102  '-', '.', '0', since '/' cannot be matched.)
00103 
00104 Complementation
00105  An expression '[!...]' matches a single character, namely any character that is not matched by the expression obtained
00106  by removing the first '!' from it. (Thus, '[!]a-]' matches any single character except ']', 'a' and '-'.)
00107 
00108  One can remove the special meaning of '?', '*' and '[' by preceding them by a backslash, or, in case this is part of a
00109  shell command line, enclosing them in quotes. Between brackets these characters stand for themselves. Thus, '[[?*\]'
00110  matches the four characters '[', '?', '*' and '\'.
00111 
00112 Pathnames
00113  Globbing is applied on each of the components of a pathname separately. A '/' in a pathname cannot be matched by a '?'
00114  or '*'  wildcard, or by a range like '[.-0]'. A range cannot contain an explicit '/' character; this would lead to a
00115  syntax error.
00116 
00117  If a filename starts with a '.', this character must be matched explicitly. (Thus, 'rm *' will not remove .profile,
00118  and 'tar c *' will not archive all your files; 'tar c .' is better.)
00119 
00120 Note that wildcard patterns are not regular expressions, although they are a bit similar. First of all, they match
00121 filenames, rather than text, and secondly, the conventions are not the same: for example, in a regular expression '*'
00122 means zero or more copies of the preceding thing.
00123 
00124 Now that regular expressions have bracket expressions where the negation is indicated by a '^', POSIX has declared the
00125 effect of a wildcard pattern '[^...]' to be undefined.
00126 */
00127

00137 enum MatchType { U_FNMATCH = 0, U_DOSMATCH = 1, U_DOSMATCH_WITH_OR = 2 };
00138 
00139 static inline void u_setPfnMatch(int match_type, int flags)
00140 {
00141         U_INTERNAL_TRACE("u_setPfnMatch(%d,%d)", match_type, flags)
00142 
00143         u_pfn_flags = flags;
00144         u_pfn_match = (match_type == U_FNMATCH  ? u_fnmatch  :
00145                                                 match_type == U_DOSMATCH ? u_dosmatch : u_dosmatch_with_OR);
00146 }

00216 #define U_URI_GEN_DELIMS  2 /* ':' '/' '?' '#' '[' ']' '@' */

00222 /* character type identification - Assumed an ISO-1 character set */
00223 
00224 extern U_EXPORT const unsigned char* u__ct_tab;
00225 extern U_EXPORT const unsigned char* u__ct_tol;
00226 extern U_EXPORT const unsigned char* u__ct_tou;
00227 
00228 static inline bool u_iscntrl(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x01) != 0; } // __C } /* Control character. */
00229 static inline bool u_isdigit(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x02) != 0; } // __D } /* Digit. */
00230 static inline bool u_islower(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x04) != 0; } // __L } /* Lowercase. */
00231 static inline bool u_ispunct(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x08) != 0; } // __P } /* Punctuation. */
00232 static inline bool u_isspace(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x10) != 0; } // __S } /* Space. */
00233 static inline bool u_isupper(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x20) != 0; } // __U } /* Uppercase. */
00234 static inline bool u_isblank(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x80) != 0; } // __B } /* Blank. */
00235 
00236 static inline bool u_isalpha( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x24) != 0; } // (__L | __U)
00237 static inline bool u_isxdigit(int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x42) != 0; } // (__D | __X)
00238 static inline bool u_isalnum( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x26) != 0; } // (__D | __L | __U)
00239 static inline bool u_isgraph( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x2E) != 0; } // (__D | __L | __P | __U)
00240 static inline bool u_isprint( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x3E) != 0; } // (__D | __L | __P | __S | __U)
00241 
00242 static inline int u_tolower(int c)       { return u__ct_tol[c]; }
00243 static inline int u_toupper(int c)       { return u__ct_tou[c]; }
00244 
00245 static inline bool u_isoctal( int c) { return ('0' <= c && c <= '7'); }
00246 static inline char u_octc2int(int c) { return ((c - '0') & 07); }
00247 static inline char u_hexc2int(int c) { return (u_isdigit(c) ? c - '0' : u_toupper(c) - 'A' + 10); }
00248 static inline bool u_isbase64(int c) { return (u_isalnum(c) || (c == '+') || (c == '/') || (c == '=')); }

00265 static inline bool u_istext(int c) { return (u_text_chars[c] != 0); }

00267 extern U_EXPORT bool u_isText(  const unsigned char* s, uint32_t n);
00268 extern U_EXPORT bool u_isUTF8(  const unsigned char* s, uint32_t n);
00269 extern U_EXPORT int  u_isUTF16( const unsigned char* s, uint32_t n);
00270 static inline   bool u_isBinary(const unsigned char* s, uint32_t n) { return ((u_isText(s,n) || u_isUTF8(s,n) || u_isUTF16(s,n)) == false); }

00272 /* ip address type identification */
00273 
00274 static inline bool u_isIPv4Addr(const char* p, uint32_t n)
00275         { char c; uint32_t i = 0; for (; i < n; ++i) { c = p[i]; if (u_isdigit(c)  == 0 && c != '.')                                    return false; } return true; } 
00276 
00277 static inline bool u_isIPv6Addr(const char* p, uint32_t n)
00278         { char c; uint32_t i = 0; for (; i < n; ++i) { c = p[i]; if (u_isxdigit(c) == 0 && c != '.' && c != ':') return false; } return true; } 
00279 
00280 static inline bool u_isIPAddr(bool IPv6, const char* p, uint32_t n) { return (IPv6 ? u_isIPv6Addr(p, n) : u_isIPv4Addr(p, n)); } 
00281 
00282 /* Quick and dirty int->hex. The only standard way is to call snprintf (?),
00283  * which is undesirably slow for such a frequently-called function... */
00284 
00285 static inline void u_int2hex(char* p, uint32_t n)
00286         { int s; for (s = 28; s >= 0; s -= 4, ++p) *p = u_hex_upper[(n >> s) & 0xf]; }
00287 
00288 static inline uint32_t u_hex2int(const char* p, uint32_t len)
00289         { uint32_t n = 0; const char* eos = p + len; while (p < eos) n = (n << 4) | u_hexc2int(*p++); return n; }

00291 #ifdef HAVE_SSL
00292 /*
00293 The u_passwd_cb() function must write the password into the provided buffer buf which is of size size.
00294 The actual length of the password must be returned to the calling function. rwflag indicates whether the
00295 callback is used for reading/decryption (rwflag=0) or writing/encryption (rwflag=1).
00296 See man SSL_CTX_set_default_passwd_cb(3) for more information
00297 */
00298 extern U_EXPORT int u_passwd_cb(char* buf, int size, int rwflag, void* password);
